description: A comprehensive overview of the principles of Value Education and the philosophy of Jeevan Vidya.

modules.moduleTitle: Core Definitions

data.text: Something that is important, worthy or useful for a human being that gives a feeling of happiness or prosperity.
The process of learning, and the acquisition of knowledge, skills, values, etc.
It deals with learning what is universally valuable to all of us and how to live in a state of continuous happiness and prosperity.

modules.moduleTitle: The Nature and Source of Values

data.title: Key Aspects of Values
points: Values define what is of worth, what is beneficial, and what is harmful.
Our values affect our decisions, goals, and behavior.
Values reflect a person's sense of right and wrong.

data.title: Where We Get Our Values
items: Ages 8-13: Influenced by teachers and heroes (sports, TV, etc.).
Ages 14-20: Peers become a major influence.
Ages 21+: Values are largely established, but may be tested from time to time.

modules.moduleTitle: The Need for Value Education

data.title: The Priority of Values Over Skills
data.text: There is an essential complementarity between values and skills, but the priority is values, then skills. The first step is understanding 'what to do', followed by developing the skills for 'how to do'.

data.title: Critique of Modern Education
data.text: The present education system has largely become skill-biased, emphasizing science and technology without a foundation of values. This can lead to serious crises at the individual, social, and environmental levels, making value education a crucial missing link.

data.title: The Ultimate Goal
data.text: The prime need of value education is to understand human aspirations, discover what is truly valuable in life, and work out a program for its fulfillment.

modules.moduleTitle: Guidelines for Value Education

items.details: It must be universally applicable to all human beings at all times and in all places, without changing based on sect, creed, nationality, or gender.
It must appeal to reasoning and logic, not be based on dogmas or blind beliefs. It cannot be a simple set of do's and don'ts.
It must be naturally acceptable to the human being and be experientially verifiable, not based on assumptions.
It needs to cover all dimensions (thought, behavior, work, understanding) and all levels (individual, family, society, nature/existence) of human life.
The ultimate aim is to promote harmony within the individual, among human beings, and with all of nature.

modules.moduleTitle: Content and Scope of Value Education

data.term: The Value of a Human Being
data.text: The value of any entity is its participation in the larger order. For a human being, this means participating in a way that ensures mutual fulfillment, starting from within oneself and extending to family, society, and all of nature.

data.title: A Holistic Scope of Study
points: To understand human values, one must study human reality in the context of the entire nature/existence.
The study must cover all dimensions of a human being: thought, behaviour, work, and realization.
The study must also cover all levels of human living: individual, family, society, nature, and existence.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 1: The Author's Aspiration and Early Conflict

data.context: After understanding ancient (Vedic) scriptures out of his own volition, the author wished for the Earth to be a certain way and found the following utterance within himself:

data.title: Upbringing and Early Dissatisfaction
data.text: The author's journey began in a hard-working, pious, and venerated family in the Vedic tradition. He started by following the path shown by his parents and teachers, but from the beginning, he was dissatisfied with the dogmas and sanctions of the tradition, such as rules like "do this - don’t do that".

data.title: The First Cause of Misery
data.text: This dissatisfaction led to his elders becoming unhappy with his attitude. This became the first cause of his misery, as he struggled between trying to make them happy and judging them against their own standards.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 2: Deepening Conflict and the Turn to Vedanta

data.title: The Crux Point and a Sacred Oath
data.text: The author realized that his revered and scholarly elders were not happy all the time, which became a crux point for him. This led him to take a 'sacred oath' to never blindly follow the dictates of tradition, a resolve that grew stronger as his elders failed to convince him with their reasoning.

data.title: The Second Cause of Misery
data.text: As his rejection of tradition grew, his elders began to worry that he was obstinately negating their beliefs without having studied the scriptures. Their worry and disapproval became the second cause of his misery.

data.title: The Study of Vedanta
data.text: With no other option, the author decided to study Vedanta, which his elders considered to be the supreme knowledge.

data.title: The Three Sections of the Vedic Path

items.details: The first section, which describes actions (karma) that, according to the Vedas, lead one to heaven.
The second section, describing the rituals and ceremonies for becoming gods and goddesses.
The third section, which states that knowledge alone is supreme.

data.title: The Riddle of Knowledge
data.text: When the author asked what this supreme knowledge was, the answer was 'knowledge of Brahman'. When he asked what Brahman was, he was told it was beyond his comprehension and that the only way to realize it was to adhere to the dictates and sanctions in the scriptures.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 3: The Paradox of Vedanta and the Path to Samadhi

data.title: The Promise of Samadhi
data.text: The author's elders assured him that realization of Brahman and answers to all his questions would happen in the state of Samadhi, a deep meditative state.

data.title: Core Philosophical Questions
items: What is bondage and what is salvation?
If salvation is the dissolution of the self (atma) into the Supreme Self (Brahman), why did Brahman place itself into living beings (jeevas) in the first place?

data.title: A Pointless Argument
data.text: His elders dismissed his persistent questioning as a pointless argument because he wouldn't blindly accept their dictates. They again insisted the answers would be found in samadhi.

data.title: Decision to Endeavor
data.text: Realizing arguments were futile, the author began preparing his mind for the endeavor of achieving samadhi, a process that started in 1944 and solidified by 1946.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 4: National Disappointment and the Journey to Amarkantak

data.title: Disappointment in National Character
data.text: Alongside his spiritual quest, the author was pained by changes he saw in leaders after Indian Independence in 1947. By 1950, he concluded that the new Constitution failed to describe the character of a 'right human being' or a national character.

data.title: The Final Attempt
data.text: Having exhausted other avenues, he and his wife decided to make one last attempt to find answers in samadhi and traveled to the sacred place of Amarkantak in 1950.

He began the agam-tantra-upasana method, a practice prescribed in scriptures for attaining samadhi. It involves visualizing gods and goddesses in parts of one's own body (an activity called 'nyas'), based on the formula 'Becoming God, worship Godhead'.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 5: The Experience of Samadhi and a New Path

data.title: Achieving a State of Pure Awareness
data.text: After dedicated practice, the author one day became free from the imagined gods and goddesses, left only with the awareness 'I am'. In this state, he had no sense of time, place, body, or thought for several hours, which he believed to be samadhi.

data.title: The Second Failure
data.text: Despite achieving this state daily for a year, no answers to his questions came. He considered this his second major failure, after not finding answers in Vedanta, and felt he was at a deadlock.

data.title: The Problem of Evidence
data.text: He then realized a new problem: there was nothing in this state that could be described, so he had no way to testify or present evidence of his experience to the world.

data.title: The Turn to Sanyam
data.text: To overcome this difficulty and test his achievement, he decided to perform 'sanyam', a method mentioned in the Patanjali Yoga Sutra.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 6: The Method of Sanyam and the Discovery of Jeevan

data.title: Improvising on Sanyam
data.text: The author found the traditional method of 'sanyam' (combining dharana, dhyan, and samadhi) to be unacceptable. He therefore improvised by reversing the prescribed order (samadhi, dhyan, and dharana). As a result of this, he began to see and understand every bit of existence, from the atom to the Earth.

In this state, he discovered the 'jeevan atom', the conscious self that is the same in every being. He understood that 'jeevan' lives with a body to use it as an instrument to evidence its presence and continues to live even after leaving the body.

data.title: The Three Stages of Jeevan's Desire
items: Jeevan first wants to live, a stage achieved in the animal world.
Thereafter, it wants to become happy.
Finally, it wants to produce evidences of being happy.

data.title: The Formula for Happiness
data.text: He discovered the formula for human happiness is 'Living in the Universal Order'. The latter two stages—becoming happy and evidencing it—are achievable only as a human being.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 7: The Order of Existence and the Role of Wisdom

items.details: All material world in solid, liquid, and gaseous states.
All organisms composed of bio-cells, based on chemical substances and fluids.

data.title: The Uniqueness of the Human Body
data.text: Human and animal bodies are both composed of physicochemical matter. The key difference is that the human body has a 'fully enriched brain', which allows jeevan (the life-atom) to express itself in a multi-dimensional way.

data.title: The Role of Wisdom in Happiness
data.text: He concluded that human happiness is possible by living according to the specific definition and order of human beings. To achieve this, a human being must become wise, as wisdom is what enables the orderly living that is happiness.

data.title: A Note on Sadhana (Spiritual Practice)
data.text: The author testifies that until he achieved samadhi, his mind had no restraint from stray thoughts, despite his resolve. He assures that this is a natural difficulty faced by all aspirants and there is no law in existence to prevent it.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 8: The Nature of Bondage and the Definition of Humanness

data.text: The author found his answer: Bondage is ignorance or illusion. Salvation is to be liberated from that illusion. The core illusion is a human living like an animal, holding animal conduct as an ideal.

data.title: Critique of Present Education
data.text: He states that prevalent traditions and modern education force us to live in this ignorance. He describes its content as 'sex-obsessed psychology, consumption-obsessed sociology, and profit-obsessed economics'. He finds it ironic that parents expect moral children from such an education.

He found the definition of a human being and 'humanness', which is the work and behavior of an awakened human being. Describing this awakened behavior becomes the Sociology or Constitution for all humanity, and imparting this understanding is its essence.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 9: The Nature of Salvation and Existence

data.title: Salvation as Liberation
data.text: Salvation is not about displaying miracles or giving blessings; it is about being liberated from illusion. This can happen mathematically in an instant, nullifying all past mistakes (sins of illusion), much like correctly learning a math problem you've gotten wrong a thousand times.

data.context: A discovered formula regarding human agreement:
lines: We humans are one in right and many in wrong.

items.details: The first reality, consisting of things which could be counted.
The second reality, which pervades everywhere and in which every unit of nature is submerged, encircled, and imbued.

data.title: Categories within Nature
data.text: Nature itself has two categories: the insentient world (material and bio orders like minerals and soils) and the sentient world (animal-kind and humankind).

modules.moduleTitle: Page 10: The Emergence of 'Madhyasth Darshan'

data.title: The Fruits of Wisdom
data.text: As a result of his sadhana and discoveries, the author achieved self-confidence, the ability to respect human excellence, and a capacity to comfortably incorporate his wisdom into his everyday life.

data.title: Five States of Being Achieved
items: 1. Self Confidence: A state achieved upon thoroughly understanding existence, jeevan, and humane conduct.
2. Balance in Talent and Personality: The ability to comfortably live with his newfound wisdom.
3. Social in Behaviour: He started getting fulfillment in himself and was left with no complaints.
4. Self-Supporting in Occupation: He came to understand the meaning of prosperity as production in excess of family requirements.
5. Self Reliance: A state of being that anyone can achieve with wisdom.

data.title: The Four Chapters of Madhyasth Darshan

items.details: Holistic view of Human Behaviour.
Holistic view of Human Actions.
Holistic view of Practices in Human living.
Holistic view of Realization in Human being.

data.title: The Essence of the Presentation
data.text: The common thread of the author's entire presentation is to explain 'madhyasth', which is why his work is named 'Madhyasth Darshan'.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 11: Understanding 'Madhyasth' and Coexistence

data.title: Creative, Destructive, and Madhyasth Powers
data.text: The author explains that there are creative (sam), destructive (visham), and 'madhyasth' powers in existence. The unique objective of humankind is to establish the magnificence of the madhyasth force. While scientists have recognized creative and destructive forces, they have not yet been able to understand the madhyasth force and power as purposiveness.

data.title: The Four Things Madhyasth Darshan Explains

data.text: The central theme is that all physical and chemical entities in nature exhibit harmony (orderly conduct) and participate in the Universal Order. This contrasts with previous theories that focused on tension or struggle between opposing forces. The author states that in reality, nature has no conflict but rather mutual complementariness and celebration of cohabitation.

data.title: Alignment with Science
data.text: Most importantly, Madhyasth Darshan's reasoning has science aligned with conscience, and conscience aligned with science. Conscience is the acceptance of purposiveness in existence.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 12: Coexistence, Consciousness, and Wisdom

data.title: The Continuity of Jeevan
data.text: 'Jeevan' is capable of carrying forward the results of human effort from one lifetime to the next. The author states that he has seen (understood) jeevan to have inexhaustible forces and powers.

data.title: Natural Excess
data.text: Whatever a jeevan decides to do with a body always turns out to be more than the needs of the body; this is a natural process.

data.title: Critique of Science's Limitations
data.text: The author argues that human beings were previously incapable of explaining consciousness and existence through education. Science, in its attempts, only demonstrated instability and uncertainty in matter, leading to ideas of inherent conflict in nature and fostering an obsession with profit, sex, and consumption. Following these scientific ideas leads to internal conflict and does not provide a basis for human fulfillment.
The author's realization is in coexistence; he has seen co-existential harmony in nature to be the content of wisdom. Wisdom manifests as resolution in every aspect of human behavior.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 13: Science, Idealism, and Human Fulfillment

data.title: The Genesis of the Proposal
data.text: This proposal is summarized as the author's focused effort to find answers to his questions after not being satisfied with the finest offering (Vedic knowledge) from tradition. As a result of this effort, he discovered that all human beings can become happy, dharma can prevail, Earth can become heaven, and humans can become godly.

data.title: The Potential for Wisdom
data.text: This proposal of wisdom is about things that are not limited to the confines of the body. Every human being has the potential for wisdom and can be inspired to achieve it with this proposal.

data.title: Science as a Step
data.text: Science is but a step in humankind's journey towards completeness, following Idealism, the Tribal Age, and the Stone Age. We must acknowledge and be grateful for the contributions of previous steps.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 14: The Chasm Between Idealism and Materialism

data.title: 'Feeling Good' vs. 'Being Good'
data.text: There is a gap between 'feeling good' and 'being good'. The example given is drinking cold water: it may feel good, but that feeling doesn't establish whether it is universally good, as it could make another person sick.

data.title: Critique of Scientific Thinking
data.text: Scientific thinking is leading humankind towards instability and uncertainty by trying to model human beings as machines, a model that human beings don't fit into. This leads to a chasm between materialism (which science advocates) and idealism (which advocates for sensitiveness, feelings, and emotions). This unresolved conflict traps humankind in problems.

data.title: A Collective Effort
data.text: The proposal the author is putting forth is the result of humankind's collective effort throughout its entire history; his individual effort is insignificant in comparison.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 15: The Role of Space and the Need for a New 'Shastra'

data.title: The Cognizance of Space
data.text: Human self-awareness begins only after recognizing Space. Understanding existence requires realizing that all units are present only in the coexistence of Space; overlooking this leads to problems and misery.

data.title: The Contradiction of Human History
data.text: All historical conflicts, revolts, exploitation, and wars contradict the principle of co-existentialism. It is surprising that humanity expected any good to result from such acts.

data.title: A Failure of Institutions
data.text: The author notes that neither the State, religion, nor education have been successful in explaining humanity's purpose or giving direction. He documented 'shastras' (theses) to describe how the wisdom of coexistence can manifest as an art of living.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 16: The Three 'Shastras' (Theses)

items.details: This thesis is proposed to pave the way for every human being's happiness, countering existing profit-obsessed economic theories.

This thesis argues that human satisfaction comes from justice (nyaya) in behavior, based on a universal humane conduct that can act as a constitution for all nations and eliminate the mentality of war.
This thesis postulates that 'jeevan' (the life-atom) is the basis of consciousness, and the body is merely a vehicle for jeevan to express that consciousness.

data.title: Documentation of Wisdom
data.text: The author's wisdom is documented in three distinct forms: 'darshan' (description of reality as it is), 'vaad' (theories based on darshan), and 'shastra' (practical guidelines for righteous living based on darshan).

modules.moduleTitle: Page 17: The Three Headings of Co-existentialism

data.title: The Three Pillars of the Author's Philosophy

items.details: Proclaims that all physicochemical nature is mutually complementary and interrelated for further emergence, inspiring humans to live in harmony.
States that human fulfillment is only achieved through harmony in behavior with other human beings, which is characterized by well-defined humane conduct.
Explains that spirituality can be understood through the empty, uniformly pervasive Space in which all units of existence are submerged and coexist.

modules.moduleTitle: Pages 18-19: The 'Yojanas' (Plans for Implementation)

data.title: From Theory to Practice
data.text: The central theme of the 'shastras' is to define orderly living for human beings. From these theories, three practical plans ('yojana') emerged to implement this vision.

items.details: Aims to remove the biggest cause of human troubles: ignorance about the self ('jeevan'). It establishes that 'jeevan' is the basis of equality among all humans, as its nature and aim (to become awakened) are universal.

items.term: 2. Humanization of Education Plan (shiksha ka manviyakaran yojana)
items.details: Aims to incorporate everything related to wisdom into education. An experimental curriculum was successfully implemented in a school, proving that students with this wisdom can positively affect their environment.

items.term: 3. Family-based Self-Organizing Order Plan (parivar moolak svarajya vyavastha yojana)
items.details: Aims to establish a social order that is centered on resolution rather than on power.

data.title: The Complete Presentation
data.text: The author's wisdom is thus presented in four complete forms: darshan, vaad, shastra, and yojana.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 20: The Nature of 'Jeevan Vidya'

data.text: The author teaches based on his understanding of 'jeevan', and this process is called 'Jeevan Vidya'. Its basic objective is to fulfill the expectation present in every human being to know about consciousness and produce evidence of that knowledge in their living.

data.title: The Constitution of Jeevan
data.text: Jeevan is a constitutionally complete atom, meaning it can neither expel nor imbibe any particles from its constitution. This is in contrast to material (physicochemical) atoms, whose constitution changes through the instillation or expulsion of particles.

items.details: Atoms that tend to imbibe more particles to fulfill their constitution.
Atoms that tend to expel some particles from their constitution.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 21: The Path to Wisdom and Order

data.title: The Flaw of Modern Systems
data.text: Controlling human behavior through fear and temptation, as is common in systems based on sensitiveness (slavery, politics, religion, business), cannot bring about a lasting order since these are not truly acceptable to a human being. Modern science, which claims everything is mechanical and there is no such thing as 'value', professes a mechanistic life of struggle, fear, and temptation that has brought humankind to the edge of annihilation.

data.title: The Path to Resolution
data.text: A problem is only solved with resolution, not by bringing in another problem. We need to develop a path that entails the Universal Order through values and valuation. We will become successful if we design our systems (education, judiciary, production) while focusing on 'jeevan's' relations, fulfillment, and aims.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 22: Understanding Jeevan and Happiness

data.text: Jeevan is an atom whose constitution has become fulfilled. It is called 'conscious' because it has the power for fully evidencing intelligence and sensitiveness. A human being participates in the Universal Order only while evidencing their intelligence and sensitiveness.

data.title: The Failed Pursuit of Happiness
data.text: In their pursuit of happiness, humans have tried luxury, possession, prayer, and penance, but there is no evidence of anyone becoming fulfilled through these means. The author states that he became successful in finding happiness through wisdom, and believes every human can do the same.

data.context: A core principle of human nature:
lines: Human beings are one when they are 'right' and are many when they are 'wrong'.

data.title: The Common Factor
data.text: To achieve universality, the common factor in all human beings needed to be recognized, and the author discovered this factor is 'jeevan'. When 'jevan' lives with wisdom, it produces resolution in all situations, which is a state of happiness.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 23: The Constant Nature of Jeevan

data.title: Constancy and Powers
data.text: While the body is in a state of continuous change, 'jeevan' has constancy. Jeevan has inexhaustible powers and forces, and it does not die or diminish. Its forces are its 'sthiti' (conscious experience), and its powers are its 'gati' (work and behavior).

data.title: Universality of Jeevan
data.text: Jeevan is equally there in all human beings, and its forces and powers are the same in everyone. Happiness is the objective of every jeevan.

data.title: Critique of Creationism
data.text: Jeevan is a constitutionally complete, conscious unit. The question 'who creates jeevan?' is tied to the premise of creationism (a creator and destroyer), which has caused frustration. The idea that we could create and destroy something that was not in existence has led to conflict, for example, with the atom bomb.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 24: The Four Stages of Evidencing Wisdom

data.title: Living with Values
data.text: Human beings ought to live with the way of values and valuation to lead a healthy and happy life.

data.title: The Four Stages of Evidencing Wisdom
items: First Stage: Acquiring wisdom (of existence as co-existential harmony).
Second Stage: Honesty (to have integrity in thought, word, and deed).
Third Stage: Taking responsibility (by recognizing one's role in the universal order).
Fourth Stage: Participation (which is to deliver according to one's role in the Universal Order).

data.title: The Three Headings of Wisdom's Content

items.details: The first step for jeevan, which is eternal and aspires for happiness.

items.term: Knowledge of Holistic View of Existence (astitva darshan gyan)
items.details: Understanding the whole existence of which jeevan is an inseparable part.

items.term: Knowledge of Humane Conduct (manviyata purna acharan gyan)
items.details: The conduct through which jeevan could evidence happiness.

data.title: Vidya (Knowledge)
data.text: To understand the whole existence in the form of co-existential harmony is itself 'vidya' or knowledge. Jeevan is the carrier of this knowledge, and the human being is the one who evidences it.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 25: Jeevan as the Entity that Understands

data.title: The Locus of Understanding
data.text: The provision of understanding (wisdom) is not located in any part of the body, but only in 'jeevan'. Jeevan is the entity that understands itself and existence. Therefore, both body and jeevan must be present to evidence wisdom; it would not happen with either one alone.

data.title: The Purpose of Wisdom
data.text: The evidence of wisdom occurs in the form of a human being's orderly living and participating in the universal order of existence. This orderly living is the purpose of wisdom, and the desire for it is innate and natural for jeevan.
'Jeevan Vidya' is the way of living for a human being. 'Vidya' has two parts: knowledge (gyan) and holistic view (darshan). Jeevan is the carrier and bearer of both.

data.title: The Nature of Equality
data.text: All jeevans are equal. This equality becomes clear when we understand the way jeevan knows itself, evidences knowledge, and evidences co-existential harmony in human living.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 26: The Formula for Happiness

data.title: Existence as Coexistence
data.text: Existence itself is coexistence because all that exists is as nature saturated (immersed, imbued and encircled) in the Omnipotence (Space). Nature is the form of entities that can be counted, and the one who counts is the human being.

data.context: The simple formula for happiness discovered by the author:
lines: happiness is from wisdom, misery is from un-wisdom

data.title: The Flawed Historical Pursuit of Happiness
data.text: Human history has been a struggle in the pursuit of happiness. First, people tried to achieve it by renouncing the world through penance and yoga, but this did not lead to a living tradition of happiness. Next, they tried achieving it by amassing material wealth, which also did not work.

data.title: The Four Stages of Realized Happiness

modules.moduleTitle: Page 27: The Centrality of Jeevan and Human Values

data.title: The Seer of Value
data.text: We cannot become happy by denying our relationship with things, whether material or with our own self (jeevan). When we ask the value of everything, the question is, 'Who is the seer of that value?'. Clearly, it is the human being who is the seer. The value of a human being has not yet been discovered by us.

data.title: Breaking the Cycle of Profit and Loss
data.text: We currently value things where there is a possibility of making a profit. It is only when we understand the value of a human being that we will become free from the mindset of profit and loss. This understanding liberates us from a vicious cycle that spares no one.

data.title: The Failure of 'Isms'
data.text: Human beings have tried to stem the excesses of the profit mentality through systems like Communism and Capitalism, but to no avail. Therefore, a human being needs to understand their values and live thereby. The way forward is by understanding jeevan and living in co-existential harmony with humane conduct, which is called wisdom.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 28: Coexistence and the Pursuit of Truth

data.title: The Way of Existence
data.text: Coexistence is the way of existence. Development is the way of coexistence. Jeevan (expression of consciousness) is the way of development. Awakening is the way of jeevan. The world is the observable reality for jeevan's awakening.

data.title: Jeevan as the Seer
data.text: It is jeevan who is the see-er (observer) of all events in the physicochemical world. The body does not understand; sensory perception happens only in those parts of the body which jeevan keeps alive.

data.title: The Eagerness for Understanding
data.text: When jeevan becomes eager for knowledge for its own fulfillment, it becomes a seeker of truth (satyata), reality (vastvikta), and meaning (yatharthta). This understanding becomes the basis of jeevan's fulfillment. This need is rich in all people, regardless of wealth or age.

data.title: The Basis for Universal Good
data.text: Knowledge of jeevan gives the basis for universal good and continuity of happiness. This knowledge establishes the principle that 'no one is alone or nothing exists in isolation'. We can live happily only when we are together with everyone else.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 29: The Four Orders of Nature and the Path to Wisdom

data.title: Wisdom as the Only Way
data.text: Past efforts to achieve happiness, such as performing rituals (yajnas) or amassing wealth, have failed to bring happiness to everyone. Wisdom is presented as the only way to happiness, and it can be taken to every human being.

items.details: Soils, stones, gems, and metals, which already evidence definite conduct.
Trees, plants, and vegetation, which evidence their respective definite conduct.
All sentient beings other than humans, which evidence order according to their essence.
Human beings, who are still awaited to get into the order of existence.

data.title: The Root of Human Misery
data.text: The author identifies the root cause of human misery as the Knowledge Order (humankind) lagging behind and not yet being in a state of order.

data.title: Belief vs. Knowing
data.text: The author notes that humans often act based on what they believe they have understood, which is different from genuine knowing. One can believe something without actually knowing it.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 30: Regulation by 'Sanskar' and Humane Conduct

data.title: The Goal of Jeevan Vidya
data.text: The entire program of Jeevan Vidya is to achieve liberation from the fundamental flaw (illusion) that has caused all human problems and frustrations.

items.details: Regulated by constitution-inheritance.
Regulated by seed-inheritance.
Regulated by specie-inheritance.
Regulated by sanskar-inheritance.

data.text: Sanskar is defined as the conclusive acceptance of wisdom. It is through sanskar that a human being becomes regulated.

data.title: Humane vs. Nonhuman Conduct
data.text: When a human becomes wise, their living becomes orderly, which is called 'humane' conduct. The absence of this capability is 'nonhuman' conduct.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 31: Wisdom as a Living Tradition

data.title: The Flow of Wisdom
data.text: Wisdom becomes a living tradition when it is passed from one generation to the next. The content of wisdom remains constant, but its presentation can become more precise over time, making it easier for new generations to live wisely.

data.title: Why Only Wisdom Can Be a Tradition
data.text: A human is a unit of 'sanskar-inheritance'. Since wrongs are never conclusively acceptable to anyone, they cannot become 'sanskar' and therefore cannot be passed down as a living tradition. Only wisdom can.

data.title: Jeevan as the Basis of Equality
data.text: The reference for equality among all humans is 'jeevan'. Every jeevan is equal due to its constitutional completeness and its undiminished, inexhaustible forces and powers.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 32: The Verification and Nature of Wisdom

data.title: How Wisdom is Verified
data.text: Wisdom is verified through one's behavior, work, and the orderliness of one's living. The author's own orderly living is evidence of his realization, even though human tradition as a whole is not yet orderly.

data.title: The Definiteness of Wisdom
data.text: Jeevan is the definite bearer and carrier of wisdom, so the evidence of wisdom is also definite. The fully developed human brain is the necessary instrument for expressing this wisdom.
The core of understanding existence is to realize it as 'Nature saturated in the Omnipotence,' meaning that nature and the omnipresent reality are eternally intertwined and inseparable.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 33: The Purpose of Human Tradition and Failure of 'Isms'

data.title: Wisdom and Order
data.text: A human being cannot live in an orderly way in family or society without wisdom. The suffering on Earth is due to this lack of wisdom, not population size.

data.title: The Purpose of Human Tradition
items: Prosperity (production in excess of family's requirements)

data.title: The Failure of Idealism and Materialism
data.text: Past endeavors of idealism and materialism have failed because they did not understand existence in the form of coexistence, which is the root cause of their inability to establish a living tradition of wisdom.

data.title: The Lack of Justice
data.text: The author notes that humankind has not yet found justice, criticizing the judicial system for passing 'judgment' instead of ensuring 'justice'.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 34: The Essence of Ethics and Human Uniqueness

data.title: The Aspiration for Wisdom
data.text: The author's movement was started with the noble aspiration of making every human being wise, which gives rise to qualities recognized as 'humane'.
Ethics is defined as devoting one's means of living (body, mind, and wealth) for a universal human purpose, which happens through production/service and in making relationships purposeful.

data.title: Protection Through Righteous Use
data.text: The righteous use of one's means of living ensures their protection. This synergy results in eternal good and is necessary for our awakening.

data.title: The Uniqueness of Being Human
data.text: A human being is the only unit in existence that can become wise. The body is a product of heredity, but 'jeevan' is a constitutionally complete atom. Their union's purpose is to evidence awakening. As a unit of 'sanskar-inheritance', humans need to learn to become complementary to the other orders of nature.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 35: Humane Ethics and the Purpose of Relationships

data.text: Humane ethics is defined as ensuring the righteous use and conservation of one's means of living: body, mind, and wealth.

data.title: The Flow of Values
data.text: Values only flow when one recognizes the purpose in their relationships. For example, the relationship with a mother is based on nurturing, and with a father, on protection. In the absence of this understanding, excesses in relationships are inevitable.

data.title: Critique of State and Religion
data.text: The author argues that both the State and Religion currently seem designed to address criminals rather than guiding normal people. They have failed to show a way of living with wisdom, honesty, and responsibility, despite people's good intentions.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 36: The Centrality of Wisdom and Justice

data.title: Wisdom as the Foundation for Justice
data.text: Wisdom is fundamental for human awakening. Living with justice—which entails resolution, prosperity, and fearlessness—is only possible if wisdom reaches every human. Justice is the backbone of humanness.

data.title: Inheritance of Wisdom or Illusion
data.text: A human being is a unit of 'sanskar-inheritance', inheriting either wisdom or illusion from their tradition. One becomes wise by imbibing wisdom from their tradition and then applying their own effort.

data.title: Critique of Body-Centric Education
data.text: The author critiques education that has only taught living with reference to the body, leading to obsessions with profit, sex, and consumption, and failing to recognize the fundamental differences between humans and animals.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 37: The Fundamental Difference Between Humans and Animals

data.title: Key Differences
items: Humans have multi-dimensional expression of jeevan and hope for resolution and prosperity; animals do not.
Humans (in illusion) willfully seek luxury and possession due to a lust for over-consumption; animals do not.
The only way out of this self-inflicted suffering is to understand jeevan, existence, and humane conduct.

data.title: Jeevan, Illusion, and Rebirth
data.text: The human is the most developed unit in existence. 'Jeevan' uses the body as an instrument but comes into illusion when it identifies with the body, leading to rebirth. This cycle is a matter of wisdom or un-wisdom, not merit or sin.
Each human can live wisely with self-reliance. This living is a combined form of values (mulya), character (charitra), and ethics (naitikta).

modules.moduleTitle: Page 38: The Path to Universal Good

data.title: The Emptiness of Slogans and False Assurances
data.text: The author argues that iterating slogans like 'good for all' is not enough, and that traditional religious assurances have proven useless.

data.title: The Universal Purpose of Relationships
data.text: Purpose is found in every relationship only upon becoming wise. This universal purpose is to achieve resolution, prosperity, trust (fearlessness), and co-existential harmony. Only wisdom can become a universal tradition.

data.title: Critique of Modern Education's Arrogance
data.text: The present education system is criticized for building up arrogance in its students, who have a false perception of their intelligence and look down on others.

data.title: The Innate Tendency for Wisdom
data.text: The author states that humans need to 'understand' before they can 'accept'. He saw that every human being has an innate tendency of seeking wisdom, which gave him the confidence to start his 'Jeevan Vidya' movement.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 39: The Aims of Jeevan and the Levels of Fulfillment

data.title: The Aims of Jeevan and the Human Being

items.details: Happiness, peace, contentment, and bliss.
Resolution, prosperity, fearlessness, and co-existential harmony.

data.title: Interconnection of Aims
data.text: When the aims of the human being are accomplished, the aims of jeevan are also accomplished. For example, Resolution = Happiness. We experience misery where we are unresolved.

data.title: How Wisdom is Evidenced
data.text: We experience prosperity while living in a family, contentment by participating in the universal order, and bliss by producing evidence of our wisdom. If we produce these evidences, wisdom will keep flowing into human tradition.

data.title: The Five Levels of Jeevan's Self-Scrutiny
The Path to Lasting Happiness
data.text: Fulfillment at these five levels of self-scrutiny is the way to lasting happiness, which is also called peace, contentment, and bliss.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 40: 'Svarajya', Justice, and Living in the Present

data.text: Svarajya is defined as the orderly, self-inspired living of humankind. Humane conduct itself is the description of svarajya.

data.title: Recognizing Purpose in the Present
data.text: The author states that we cannot live in the eternal presence of existence until we recognize the purpose and meaning in our relationships. Trying to live in past memories or future hopes leads to listless wandering.

data.title: Wisdom as the Path to Purposeful Living
data.text: Upon becoming wise, every human can become a living evidence of that wisdom. It is through this that humankind can achieve a continuous tradition of happiness and live purposefully.
Justice is defined as harmony in human relations, which is achieved by recognizing purpose in those relations, fulfilling values, and achieving mutual fulfillment.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 41: Wisdom, Prosperity, and the Nature of Existence

items.details: Food, shelter, and utilities.
Transportation and telecommunication.

data.title: Achieving Prosperity Through Wisdom
data.text: With wisdom, we can definitively know our physical requirements based on jeevan's activity and thus achieve production and experience prosperity. This leads to orderly living and enables self-reliance.

data.title: The Three Levels of Evidencing Wisdom
The Content of Wisdom
data.text: The content of wisdom that needs to be understood is 'existence', 'jeevan', and 'humane conduct'.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 42: The Illusion of Exploitation vs. the Truth of Coexistence

data.title: The Hope for Fulfillment
data.text: Human beings move towards evidencing resolution, prosperity, and trust in the hope of fulfillment. Truth is existence itself, which is eternal and in the form of coexistence.

data.title: The Pervasive Illusion of Exploitation
data.text: The author is surprised how humans could imagine happiness through exploiting nature. This belief is accepted by all nations, sects, and families, and is propagated by science through slogans like 'Might is Right' and 'Survival of the Fittest'.
A developed nation is one that has become awakened and aligned to the universal order of existence, whose people are resolved and prosperous, and who live by co-existential harmony.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 43: The Failure of 'Isms' and the Path Forward

data.title: Critique of Individualism
data.text: Both prior thoughts of idealism and materialism resulted in making human beings individualistic and could not provide a formula for an undivided, harmonious society.

data.title: The Second Plan: Humanization of Education
data.text: The author proposes equipping those who are ready to understand now, so they can teach and instill 'sanskar' in children through the educational institutions.

data.title: Humankind's Undecided State
data.text: While the other orders of nature (material, bio, animal) are complementary to human beings, humankind is still undecided on whether to become complementary to the other orders.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 44: The Five Activities of Jeevan (Part 1)

data.title: The Nature of Jeevan's Activities
data.text: Jeevan's activities can be seen in five parts, each with two conscious activities: 'sthiti' (state of being) and 'gati' (response in mutuality).

data.title: The First Two Activities of Jeevan

items.details: Selection is the activity for 'taste'. The part of jeevan performing this is 'mun'. The author critiques the amassing of possessions to satisfy this taste, as it has not led to fulfillment.

Jeevan analyzes reasons to recognize the purpose of things. The purpose of human life is to evidence resolution, prosperity, trust, and co-existential harmony, as opposed to a life of unstable over-consumption.

data.title: Critique of Present Science
data.text: The author notes that the present scientific worldview concludes that its path will lead to the annihilation of the human race and the destruction of the Earth.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 45: Humankind's Purpose and the Nemesis of Lust

data.title: Humanity's Wrong Turn
data.text: Although Earth provided conditions conducive to human awakening, humankind instead drifted towards an endless pursuit of luxury and possession.

data.title: The Nemesis of Lust
data.text: This lust is humanity's nemesis because the Earth lacks the resources to fulfill it for everyone. Possessions should instead be devoted to their purpose: nurturing the body and enabling social progress.

data.title: The Aim of Jeevan
data.text: As humans turn their efforts toward social progress and universal order, their living becomes feasible. In this way, 'jeevan's' sole aim is to evidence human awakening.

data.title: The Requirement for Order
data.text: Order requires recognizing justice in place of fear and temptation, and for that, we need to develop our understanding.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 46: The Objective of Living and Capabilities from Wisdom

data.title: The Objective of Human Living
data.text: The objective of living is focused on the human desire to live with happiness. The procedure to achieve this is for 'jeevan' to achieve its own objective, which is accomplished through wisdom.

data.title: Evidence of Orderly Living
data.text: A fulfilled 'jeevan' is able to sustain the human aims of resolution, prosperity, trust, and co-existential harmony. This state is the evidence of orderly living. Coexistence itself is order.

data.title: The Meaning of 'Learned'
data.text: These capabilities are good qualities. Learning is defined as evidencing wisdom in living. Therefore, only a human being who understands existence can be called 'learned'.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 47: The Nature of Exploration and Coexistence

data.title: Jeevan as the Locus of Understanding
data.text: 'Jeevan' is the entity that understands. It understands the entire existence in the form of coexistence. A human becomes capable of orderly living—which is happiness—only through this co-existential outlook.

data.title: Exploration as an Intrinsic Tendency
data.text: When human living is in disorder (due to illusion), 'jeevan' begins exploring for resolution. This tendency for exploration and harmony is intrinsic to every atom in nature.

data.title: Inseparability from Coexistence
data.text: Human beings are an inseparable part of coexistence. Every attempt to escape it has only led to more misery. Every human has a natural right to seek order, and happiness is the objective of this seeking.

modules.moduleTitle: Page 48: The Four Human Activities

data.title: The Four Activities of a Human Being
Humanity's Unique Activities
data.text: While exploration is innate to all of existence, learning is only possible in humans. All other orders in nature (material, bio, animal) operate on the basis of 'recognizing and responding'. Human beings have two additional, unique activities: 'knowing and believing'.

data.title: The Path to Fulfillment
data.text: A human being becomes fulfilled and assured only when their knowing and believing are based on understanding the purpose of everything. Without this, one cannot become social or evidence co-existential harmony.

data.title: The Cause of the Wretched Condition
data.text: The author states that humanity's wretched condition is a result of having the potential for knowing and believing but failing to achieve it. The focus must be on developing this aspect. Learning is to evidence wisdom in the form of a living tradition.
